posts.name: Just Like That
posts.com:
>>21544332

Just like that, sipping their lattes,
the dog sleeping on the floor,
in their favourite little cafe
at a table by the door,

Just like that, a minor quarrel had ballooned
like a live thing, like an unfurling demon.
Grievances became confessions, as each said things to wound,
in a kind of mad, cathartic, loss of reason.

Just like that, they had broken up.
He stared at the still-sleeping dog.
She simply sat, purged, aghast, numb.
But the thing had been done.

They both affected relief, ("we make more sense as friends"),
But their eyes met and they sorrowed, and then of course followed guilt,
and dismay at the life so quickly discarded,
that had been so lovingly built.

The dog woke, and looked from one to the other,
and it was then that she began to cry,
as he stared out at the leaves blustering past,
vertiginous with the still-telescoping enormity of it all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Past and future fall away.
There is only the rose and blue
Shimmer of the illimitable
Sea surface.
No Place.
No Time.

Slowly the moon rises
Over the quiet sea.
Slowly the face of my beloved
Forms in my mind.

The new moon has reached
The half. It is utterly
Incredible. One
Month ago we were strangers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I cannot comprehend the depths of you:
Oh, how I must appear so small and weak—
A madman shouting—pleading—at the stars
For an answer to lull the soul to sleep.

From the cup of life your love overflowed
To imbue the mind and nourish the heart
You are the tailor whose might interwoven
Material and ethereal heart.
I cannot fathom the logic of you:
Why require such a cruel test of faith—
And desire both fool and wise to praise—
Why gift logic yet demand steadfast faith?

But when I drift beneath a star-lit sky
And ponder this absurdity called life
There I find faith in the azure magpie,
The bumblebee, wasp, and marigold rife.
I cannot describe the nature of you:
Do you live in me; do I live in you?
In His face I think I find an answer—
To treat each log as if it were a pew.

At a small pond I throw a rounded stone
And in the water I see myself strange:
I become crooked and foul and unknown—
But did I in soul veritably change?
Is life but a false reflection of you?
For the world is wicked yet you are true.

Ah, ma petite fleur
The room is dark
And rain laps the silence
Pattering on my windows
Lonely
In a chill January room

But you
Fleur pâle de mai
You are light
Flush
Pink
Pink and ripe
Plucked from the greenhouse
Humid
A palette of warmth
Cherries on your cheeks
Pomegranate lips
With flavor bursting
Moist
Ready
Oh, so sweet
Oh, so sweetly framed
The lines
The freckles
La fraises
La graines de fraise
The innocence of those
Seeds
The irony of that thought
Of innocence
Oh, ma semence
Oh, je voudrais semer
La fraises

The glint on that pomegranate
Those perfect teeth
Pillowed tongue
Flesh
Inner flesh
A l'intérieur de la grenade
Laisse moi le goûter
Laisse moi le sentir
Let me kiss those strawberry seeds

AND

And let me grab that bird
Beneath green
Roosting, mocking
That tufted wristband
Grab and
Wrench away her arm
And see that deeper pink
Circled pink
Textured, rising pink
Pink and ripe
Another fruit to savor
Un autre fruit à embrasser

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
deep in the trenches of the profane
plumbline undergirding
this home's undeniable architecture
swims a nameless face
affixed with body black and serrated
bulbous in searing mind

its hunger grows its own offspring
and as a pressure it finds a new light
peeking through the echoing drains
their percolating throatsongs sing blank songs

the number of rooms divides equally
among the lives that lie
in the bedframe cracks
no family here can ignore the urge
to dissolve away into the seamless recessions
blurred at the edges by screen static's
temporal yawn

and conspiracies don't explain the extent
to which archaeological blueprints predict
the needling green scents
of pine-room ecstasies labeled wine
vintage dated at a future location

granny's patchwork quilt
has no story to tell
until the dregs excavate
their own internal inconsistencies
stitched by cellular junctions
quizzling scientists call causality's reign

This is translated into English: I lie like a carcass
with a soul so bright
The body stands strong
yet the breath stays fading
I violently grab onto the light
but it doesn't want to come out

Chokes extinguishing stars

Holds onto untamed fire

To stand and pridely caw

Has vowed it mute

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Saw this thread this morning, so i threw this poem together inbetween my errands to participate. It's been too long. It's nothing profound. And certainly not perfect. But I can see the evolution of my own mentality in what I desire to capture in my poetry from what I used to before shifted to prose. So for that, I like it. It's similar still, but is more grounded and not afraid to capture dis-ease--which I was always adamantly avoiding doing.

Fae-kin
------------

Twirl to leaves in zephyr eddies
does the Fae-kin do with whimsy
just beside a forest river.

Freshly loosened are the leaves whose
supple stems have broken from the
recent fall of each their branches.

Wooden carts then carry off the
limbs and husks of butchered redwoods
while they're pulled by beasts of burden.

Snapping whips break air then skin as
Swinging axe thunks wooden limb while
so the Fae-kin dance in rhythm.

Let art be an expression of the self
For there is too much fiction on your shelf
And if you cannot deduce who you are
From sharing drink with stranger at the bar
Then I doubt you’ll find yourself in book read
Of another man’s life who lived and bled
All the things you dream about in the night
Whilst you cower beneath your covers tight
Are you not afraid of dying unborn?
Do you truly believe people will mourn?
You are nothing but a stain on the Earth—
Oh, if only you’d known what you could have been worth.

Anybody here have experience owning or working in a book store? I'm curious about the business as whole. Not just the money but also what makes a book store fail/succeed and how you decide what's worth ordering in and what remains online-only. I also wonder if such businesses have any influence on what's popular or if they just follow trends like everybody else.

I ask this after struggling to find a novel I wanted in my library. I supposed that libraries wouldn't carry obscure books because of poor funding, so I scoured all 4 book shops in my city. Lo and behold, they all have essentially the same inventory: Incomplete fantasy series (except for Deltora Quest with is always complete), some of the classics and a huge preference for biopics. What's even the point of a bookshop if that's what you sell?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21556562
>What's even the point of a bookshop if that's what you sell?
Nobody reads books, so the best you can do is stock books that appeal to people who aspire to be the sorts of people that read books. Don't forget to sell coffee.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21556562
I am part owner of a book store. What makes a bookstore succeed is knowing what your clientele wants and not making it about what you think a book store should be. Most book stores base their stock off of what people buy and what people order, not what they want to sell. If you want a book store to start carrying what you want then start ordering books through them, if they see a pattern they will start stocking that sort of thing. Worst case is they will get to know you and your tastes and provide you with solid recommendations.

Most of the classics do not sell well since the used market is overflowing with them and you can walk into a used book store and get them in perfect condition for a fraction of the price, which is what most readers do.

As an aside, I really miss the banned book threads, I made good money from them as they always insured a bunch of people showing up for those "banned" books in the coming weeks so I always ordered a nice stock of any books mentioned in those threads.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21556747
>Can I ask how the shop has been going in general? Any trends over the years?
/pol/ shit (both left and right) has dramatically dropped off since Biden which is nice since those sorts always want to demonstrate how enlightened they are. The Obama and Trump years were hell for this. Other than that there has not been much change, you get the random surges for books after some celebrity talks about them or a movie is made but other than that there is not much for trends for us.
>So what is a new store with no sales history meant to do?
Market research and blind guesses. Really just a lot of what is popular and a bunch of niche stuff to separate you. Talk to the people who come and and listen to what they have to say. When we started the shelves were mostly every best seller list/award long list of note, a pile of classics and currently trending non-fiction/hobbies/etc, random stuff we liked and loads of zines since those were still a thing back then. When ever someone ordered a book we always ordered two copies, one for them and one for the shelves and often we ordered some related stuff especially if other people had inquired or ordered similar or they were regulars who liked to browse.

Book clubs are also good, give a good discount to book clubs for their selections just to get them to send their members your way and get them in the door. We sell book club selections at cost, any book club can sign up with us, they provide us with what their next book is and the number of copies needed and we keep them behind the counter for their members who generally buy a few other books when they stop by to get the club selection.
> I suppose this is because normies are told (often rightfully so) that these books are good starting points.
Pretty much, we have about 200 classics that we have kept in stock for years now because the are goto entry points for literature and we don't stock or sell much else for classics. We keep a random selection of another 100 or so lesser known classics for the readers who like to browse and just happen onto something new but that is about it and these are just mixed in with the general fiction since that sort has already read the standards and has no desire to sift through hundreds of books they have already read in search of that one they have not.
>once they're hooked they'll have to order the rest in?
Most people are not completionists and would rather have a bit more variety than spending all that time with a single author. 90% of people who fixate on authors seem to have shit comprehension and are just looking to check them all off of their list. Most avid readers tend to just have a few authors who they have read all of and mostly cast a wide net.

posts.com:
My dad started reading The Hobbit to me and my ADHD brother when we were kids, but my brother didn't stay still so one night my dad just stopped reading it.

It drove me nuts, so I took the book and finished it myself.

We were very poor so we spent a lot of time at the library since it was free, and I grabbed The Lord of the Rings and read the entire thing by age 10.

After that I read everything my dad would recommend, Saga of Pliocene Exile, Dragon riders of Pern, etc.

Moved on to classics later on and horror, then more. I was the first in my family to ever go to college and he bought me a Kindle Paperwhite as a graduation present, I still use it.

He passed away a couple of years ago, but I still have dreams of walking into the forest behind one of the places we rented when I was a kid, and he's there sitting on a log by a fire and we talk about the books I've read recently and other things.

Thanks, dad.

>>21553314
Mom read the Hobbit to me as bedtime stories when I was little. One day I notice there are all these other books on the shelf by the same man, and I go berserk with excitement and make her read them too, despite her misgivings that there was scary stuff in there. Yeah! read me the scary stuff Mom!

So sure as shit, a few weeks later I'm having chronic nightmares about the Nazgul coming to carry me off and waking up crying and shrieking, and it gets so bad Dad unloads the bedside stand gun -- it was an old wartime bring-back Walther P-38 -- and puts it on *my* bedside stand. Here, bub. This'll keep the shadows from Mordor away. Which worked, because not even the Nazgul will fuck with a Walther P-38.

Anyway. Yeah. That was my introduction to grownup literature. Later on I got into Howard Pyle and Edgar Allen Poe and all the 19th century greats. Then I got into everything else. They're addictive, books are.

posts.com:
The man's uniform was in impeccable condition. The whites of his puffy marshmallow hat and skin-tight gloves gleamed in the sun like freshly fallen snow on the peak of Mount Tabaeksan. Despite working long days in the street, his Thomas-the-Tank-Engine-blue pants and jacket still looked fresh off the sweatshop assembly line. The white moon runes on his red and blue DPRK armband, too, seemed freshly printed. They likely told of his position or departmental affiliation as such adornments often did. To me though, they were just a series of lines and circles; familiar enough in their patterns to be identified as the hieroglyphics of some oriental script, but nothing more.
He turned to look in my direction. He had a look on his face, but I couldn't tell what it was due to the shadow cast by the short bill of his cap and the dark sunglasses he wore. What I could tell, or feel rather, was the intensity of his gaze. In that moment, I felt the full biting force of a Pyongyang winter projected clearly through squinty eyes and a thick layer of polarized glass.

>It isn't just this for me but I'm quite convinced that Jesus himself was gnostic, to me the belief system behind it lines up more with what he says even in the Canon.
Went through this same arc myself starting like five years ago, if you care to listen I may save you some trouble.
1.Gnosticism is one of many attempts within Christianity at setting up a formal esoterism. No attempt succeeded (in western Christianity at least, not sure about Orthodoxy) in setting up an official, widely accepted esoterism, but there are many attemps and Gnosticism is one flavor. Rather than Gnosticism specifically you might just be craving esoterism that's attached to the figure of Jesus in general.
2. It doesn't matter what the historical Jesus actually taught or was like, nobody can assert this in an objective sense, they just have faith in one narrative or another regarding who he was. I too went through a phase of feeling convinced that the "real Jesus" was Gnostic, for the simple reason that the Gnostic texts spoke very powerfully to me. The simple truth is the real Jesus is in your heart and has to be sought spiritually rather than historically.
3. If Gnosticism is your thing that's great but don't forget the focus always has to be on spiritual discipline, don't let Gnosticism just be some alternative narrative for you and that's it. I personally moved more toward perenilliasm but I still have a fondness for Gnosticism. Remember the focus has to be on spiritual discipline.
Hope that was helpful in some sense, if not our experiences are more different than I perhaps assumed. I realize this is unsolicited advice so if you brush it off I won't be offended. In any case may God bless you and I hope you find what you seek.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21553508
Just going there for five minutes is the first step. Literally anyone is physically capable of being in a gym for their entire lives, or at least until they get kicked out. The entire essence of a CBT-focused methodology is getting your brain more in line with reality. Going to the gym for five minutes enough times (it may only take one time) might convince you that you can go for ten minutes. Once you become comfortable with just being in the gym, you might walk on a treadmill, because it gets pretty boring just being in a gym for ten minutes without doing anything. The point is to treat it all incrementally, and to recognize that even if there are some people who might think it's weird to stand around in a gym without doing anything, they're not the ones who have problems with it. They are irrelevant to you being in the gym. And, hey, you're paying to be there so you have as much a right to use the space as they do.

>>21553784
The premise is that the very “world” of thoughts, conceptual thinking, or the source of thinking, itself forms its own analogous “realm” or “world,” even if it’s not an adjacent one-to-one parallel to the three-dimensional (or four- with time, a modern addition) sensate space-time world we take as “observable and verifiable physical reality.”

It’s an analogous but more sophisticated idea to that of certain shamanic cultures of a “dreamtime” realm, spirit-world, metaphorical Underworld or even Upper World (Harner’s systematization of shamanism also adds a Middle World, all with different qualities and entities residing in them than each other, and all accessible to the shaman), reachable through altered states of consciousness such as a trance state (such as brought about by repetitive drumming), the dream state, hallucinogenic drugs, and the like. And even while these realms are “reachable” by human beings, and can even interpenetrate with and have an influence on what we call “ordinary physical reality” or “real life” despite one’s skepticism of them — so, phenomenologically, they are at least “real” in that sense, even if we claim they don’t have the coherence and verifiable qualities of “real life physical reality.”

However, in the case of Plato and Socrates, the belief is much more philosophical, with the World of Forms being the very source of our conceptual thinking, our highest thoughts like “the True,” “the Good,” “the Beautiful.” For the ancients, the idea that, “It’s only real if you can touch, taste, smell, hear or see it” is a crude and plebeian one, as we also have the metaphorical sixth sense of “mind,” and a whole realm of values and experiencing (through the emotions and thoughts) which can’t be neatly categorized by these or hand-waved away by scientism, reductionism, physicalism, or eliminative materialism (in the vein of Daniel Dennett’s “Consciousness (Not) Explained”).

The great masses could be saved, if only with the gravest sacrifice in time and patience.

At that time I was still childish enough to try to make the madness of their doctrine clear to them; in my little circle I talked my tongue sore and my throat hoarse, thinking I would inevitably succeed in convincing them how ruinous their Marxist madness was; but what I accomplished was often the opposite. The more I argued with them, the better I came to know their dialectic. First they counted on the stupidity of their adversary, and then, when there was no other way out, they themselves simply played stupid. If all this didn't help, they pretended not to understand, or, if challenged, they changed the subject in a hurry, quoted platitudes which, if you accepted them, they immediately related to entirely different matters, and then, if again attacked, gave ground and pretended not to know exactly what you were talking about. Whenever you tried to attack one of these apostles, your hand closed on a jelly-like slime which divided up and poured through your fingers, but in the next moment collected again. But if you really struck one of these fellows so telling a blow that, observed by the audience, he couldn't help but agree, and if you believed that this had taken you at least one step forward, your amazement was great the next day. The Jew had not the slightest recollection of the day before, he rattled off his same old nonsense as though nothing at all had happened, and, if indignantly challenged, affected amazement; he couldn't remember a thing, except that he had proved the correctness of his assertions the previous day.

Sometimes I stood there thunderstruck.

I didn't know what to be more amazed at: the agility of their tongues or their virtuosity at lying.

Gradually I began to hate them.

Reading is not an end in itself, but a means to an end. Its chief purpose is to help towards filling in the framework which is made up of the talents and capabilities that each individual possesses.[1]
On the other hand, a man who possesses the art of correct reading will, in studying any book, magazine, or pamphlet, instinctively and immediately perceive everything which in his opinion is worth permanently remembering, either because it is suited to his purpose or generally worth knowing. I do not know which is more terrible: inattention to social misery such as we see every day among the majority of those who have been favored by fortune or who have risen by their own efforts, or else the snobbish, or at times tactless and obtrusive, condescension of certain women of fashion in skirts or in trousers, who 'feel for the people.' In any event, these gentry sin far more than their minds, devoid of all instinct, are capable of realizing. Consequently, and much to their own amazement, the result of their social 'efforts' is always nil, frequently, in fact, an indignant rebuff, though this, of course, is passed off as a proof of the people's ingratitude.

Such minds are most reluctant to realize that social endeavor has nothing in common with this sort of thing; that above all it can raise no claim to gratitude, since its function is not to distribute favors but to restore rights.

I was preserved from studying the social question in such a way. By drawing me within its sphere of suffering, it did not seem to invite me to 'study,' but to experience it in my own skin. It was none of its doing that the guinea pig came through the operation safe and sound.

You kind of can if you know where to look. Throughout the book there are statements which are basically the foundation of the ideology. At that point however they were not yet gatherd in a clear list or chapter but just strewn about so you really have to know where to look to understand it. Later SS works clearly translated this in 4 so called life laws which made up the ''racist worldview'' which is more accurately called a natural worldview since it is largely based on biological concepts. Hitler himsels referred to these in Mein Kampf as the eternal laws or the laws of the natural order with the term life laws being taken later from the biologist and volkist Raoul Francé (who I believe came up with it only in 1920). One SS pamphlet that is translated for example called SS Race Theory and Mate Selection Guidelines starts off naming all of them shortly (though misses a lot of the broader applications and their philosophical grounding)

As for a ''racist view of history'', there largely isn't one. Some early National Socialists like Rudolf Jung in his book National Socialism: It's Foundations, Development, and Goals and some later ones like Rosenberg still believed in the idea that at some point there was a natural racial ecology which got disturbed but there is little evidence Hitler ever believed this with it in general becoming less popular in the actual third reich. All that really matters in history is that small and weak states aren't able to protect themselves and thus become dependant on other nations protecting them or are wiped out, thus Germany must be big and strong. That's what he means when talking about kleinstaaterei of the HRE being bad. This is based on the life law of struggle and since this struggle can be done through many methods there is not one factor in history that is causing all or most of it like in Marxism, it just is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21551466
From their time period? The general population mostly had to know only the application of the ideology so weren't educated as much in the full background. So writing was largely left to the SS or high up party members which of course was a far smaller group who then made mostly short books or articles. So as far as I'm aware there is not one grand overarching book covering the whole ideology. Also very few books the SS made are translated. Their economic policy also was not fully developed but if you want some from that period the 3 main books of gottfried feder are pretty close to Hitlers views. Italian Fascism actually has the same problem which is why some historians viewed it as having no clear ideology or it just being irrational, they just didn't write that much of it down. Shame National Socialism doesn't have someone who can make sense of it like A.J. Gregor did for Fascism. With the BUF it's the exact opposite. Mosley was nothing that special and of course completely failed in the end but simply by writing so many books he is still known and celebrated by some. Rockwell same thing, an unimpressive wannabe führer is known because his books are still around.

So, sorry but I can mostly just recommend more post-war stuff.
As for a clear breakdown of the life laws, one came out not too long ago which I'd say is pretty good:
National Socialism: Its Principles and Philosophy - Carlos Videla

For the economic ideology of the upper National Socialists a pretty nice short summery is:
The Nazi War Against Capitalism - Nevin Gussack

This book also is also very well done on many of Hitlers personal views:
Hitler's National Socialism - Rainer Zitelmann

If you want to know about pre-Hitlerism National Socialist ideology the first ever NatSoc book is best:
National Socialism: It's Foundations, Development, and Goals - Rudolf Jung

Much more of the books and collections of articles/short works from many party members have actually been getting translated by two publishers since last year. So maybe in 10 years or so we'll have a full ideology book be available.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
> Are American postmodern writers read in other countries?
That pretty much depends on a country's postmodern writing tradition.
In Russia, for example, postmodernist literature exploded in popularity in the 90's because the Soviet literature had bored everyone to death but there were no "classic" alternatives, so now there's still some guy doing a novel a year about the popular thing and everyone knows and reads his works, but some writers did not survive the heat after 2014 and fizzled out. The works made by the local postmodernists are closer to their own lifestyle so people would rather read dialogues about Russia's entry into the Western values market or delve into an alternate universe in which everyone still serves the Tsar and does cocaine in the drug stores than whatever the Westerners are concerned with, even if they like the West more. I know a Russian guy who read a lot of Pynchon and shit and even read the entirety of Ulysses, but he's a giant English literature nerd anyway.
Americans specifically-wise, probably anecdotal but i've seen as much attention for stuff like Foster Wallace as for stuff like Cyclonopedia. Some cults form, they translate the thing (recently they've translated Finnegan's Wake and Infinite Jest), but they stay in the cult and it does not expand. People prefer the "vanilla" stuff like To Kill a Mockingbird or All the King's Men more.

posts.name: Anonymous

Disclaimer: I am Catholic.

Obviously the knee-jerk answer is the Bible but I assume OP wants something more interesting.

My favorite spiritual writer is Saint Teresa of Avila. I consider her the greatest of the Catholic mystics and I have read multiple books by her. I recently read The Way of Perfection and I was struck by how simple it all is. So very different than any kind of hermeticism or esoteric thought. Teresa says that the depths of holiness are available to all because there is no secret in Christian teaching. She speaks of three things: love for one another, detachment from all created things, and true humility. Every Christian can practice these. But those who are truly holy will advance in them, and find the infinity hidden in such seemingly simple things. Teresa demonstrates this in The Way Of Perfection by devoting a huge chunk of the latter half of the book to an extended commentary on the Our Father, drawing very intense spiritual meditations out of the most basic of all Christian prayers.

So if you're looking for spiritual writings, she's a good guide. All the mystics are fruitful writers, but I like her the best.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21556171
I read this yesterday, and it really nailed for me why I dislike academia so much. I had a professor in undergrad who tried to encourage me to go into academia, and while it might have been pleasant enough to work at a small liberal arts college like the one I attended, with no publishing pressures, the state of the field just seemed so oppressively boring. The journal mill and the endless granularity and utter irrelevance of theses would drive me bonkers. I see friends who are getting their PhDs, and when I see the conferences they attend and papers they publish, I'm so glad I'm not there.

I think a big problem has been the attempt to bring humanities in line with science departments: the publish or die mindset combined with the insistence on critical apparati as if they were scientific frameworks. It's all just so far away from why anyone does or should write or read that of course there's a constant crisis of self-justification.

But at the same time, it's all so very frustrating because there has never been more of a need. It seems as if the whole world has lost the ability to parse information critically. Popular discourse is looney. And the discussion around ChatGPT is maddening, what with seeing people (even from respectable publications) talk as if it's putting out brilliant student-quality essays.

More than ever we need to teach people how to read, speak, and write, how to be articulate, thoughtful, and discerning. And literature is the best way to do that. No, teaching students to write 3.5 essays or draft emails or social media posts (or whatever the hell new media and communications studies is) isn't teaching communication skills; it's teaching them to be monotonous and intellectually barren. Honestly, we shouldn't be surprised that after teaching a generation of people that thinking robotically is smart writing, we've now mistaken literal robotic prose as somehow intelligent.

>>21538358
I never liked the idea of proclaiming anyone "the greatest", even if one day I would have read enough to compare. One can usually tell who would be a bad writer, but among the good ones it's usually a matter of nuances, and there is the fact different people like different things.
I find Balzac rather dull, but I can see why someone else would love his work. Maupassant is also good, although I'd have to read more to give a proper opinion. Verne is definitely most friendly to an ordinary reader, which is not really a critique of his style (never read him in french), but the fact the themes he tackles are really interesting. Everybody loves a good adventure.

Honorary mention to Maurice Leblanc, who may not have had the best prose, but definitely had the best main character.

Stendhal.
The Red and the Black was the most impressionable novel I'd ever read when I read it in high school. I picked it out knowing nothing about it and it blew me away. It was my first exposure to "real" literature and no novel has given me the same impression since.
Stendhal's talents extend outside of the novel as well. He has a wonderful collection of essays on the philosophy of love.
To put forward a less popular nomination, I'd also recommend Marguerite Duras.

>>21539654
Not that anon, and while I wouldn't say Celine "rocked my world apart," I did find Journey to the End of the Night highly entertaining, and it did make me think. I think each chapter sort of functions as its own essay addressing a different philosophical topic. And Bardamu shouldn't just be chalked up to a "life is absurd humans are le bad type." Bardamu does recognize life as absurd undoubtedly, but part of this absurdity is the inexplicable goodness of some men. Take Alcide for example. He ends the chapters involving Alcide by writing that he wishes "there were some mark to distinguish good men from bad." Alcide's account is heart-breaking.

posts.com:
There wouldn't be /lit/ at all if there weren't letters. Even before printing there were distinct and recognisable 'types' of writing, and now after 500 years of printing in Europe and about twice as much in China there are a whole lot more. You're looking at a typeface right now. Even if you don't notice typography, you are still noticing it.

In this thread, discuss typography and topics related to typography. What fonts do you like? Dislike? What fonts do you use in your everyday typing? What's an example of a particularly well-typeset book? Do you think sans-serif fonts for body text in printed books are hard to read? Does bad kerning make you grind your teeth? Is there a particular font you've seen somewhere but can't identify? Any and all questions are welcome.

---Classic Books on Typography---
—Bringhurst, Robert. The Elements of Typographic Style
—Dowding, Geoffrey. Finer Points in the Spacing and Arrangement of the Printed Word.
—Gill, Eric. An Essay on Typography.
—Lawson, Alexander. Anatomy of a Typeface.
—Tschichold, Jan. The New Typography.
—McLean, Ruari. The Thames and Hudson Manual of Typography.
—Heller, Steven; Meggs, Philip B. Texts on Type: Critical Writings on Typography.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21552692
>Do you have any opinions on the optional programming ligatures in Fira Code? They turned me off, seems like a useless boondoggle sort of thing.
I've only used them extensively with JetBrains Mono. I'm ambivalent. At first I liked them, but I recently had to switch from a 4K screen at 2x scaling to a 1440p screen at 1x, and I realized the != ligature is really hard to read. It prevented me from noticing a bug for several minutes because I didn't see the tiny slash across the double equals. So now I tend to keep them off. Maybe if I switch back to a Hi-DPI screen I'll try them again. I think they provide a nice effect that's similar psychologically to haptic feedback. When you press == and it pops into the double equals sign, something in your brain clicks and you're happy to continue typing.

>>21551300
Although it is true that there are similarities, causation in the sciences is extremely hard to prove.

In scientific investigations, the correlational study is about knowing the relationship between two variables, not neccesarily that one causes the other. Just because a relationship between two variables exists, which there obviously will be in any causation, does not mean the correlation is causation.

A causation or explicative study gives a comprehensive understanding of the studied phenomenon and explains why the phenomenon occurs, what conditions it manifests itself in, and why the two or more variables are related.

The correlational study is about knowing the relationship between two or more variables, concepts or categories in a specific context. Its useful for knowing how a variable behaves knowing the behaviour of the other variables being studied. They predict the APPROXIMATE value of a variable in respect to another variable.

In the explicative or causal scope of investigation, all types of investigations are used, not just the correlational investigation.

That being said, the book Sex and Culture does attempt more or less to establish a causal relationship between sexual restraint and the cultural achievement. Is this attempt at establishing a causal relationship correct? Maybe, but what I am sure of is that these cultures that Urwin studies certainly had a variety of different social, economic, and cultural factors other than sexual restraint that made them decay. These societies experimented war, economic downturns, leadership problems and other issues. These societies were not brought down solely because of sexual restraint, although this factor is very influential.

That being said the book establishes a correlation of past cultures and societies before the industrial revolution. The past 200 years have changed the entire landscape of the productive and social relations in human societies, which means the such relations, although important, are not neccesarily irrevocable as Urwin says. We can certainly try to better the social conditions which have brought the modern societal decay(extreme economic inequality, lack of social trust, alienation, shitty goverment structures).

We must look forward to the future brothers, and struggle and fight for a better one, even in a decaying society. Then again, if we dont fight, who will?

>>21551300
The problem is that assuming causation is an easy trap to fall into. Correlation tells you that two things are co-occurring. This *could* be because one is causing the other, but it could also be that something else is causing both. Bold mathematical speculation: Could it be true that it's less likely one causes the other considering that there are myriad other potential factors that could be causing both? I don't enough math to say if that makes any sense. But anyway, the problem is that humans psychologically default to assuming causation. A causal mechanism needs to be proposed at the very least (it's often not), but ultimately an experiment with a control group needs to be run. But that's very difficult and often unethical in many situations.

Austen and Shakespeare are the only authors I've read who achieve objective psychological realism. Other great authors warp the characterization of side characters to cast the essential conflict of the protagonist into sharper relief, or to polemicize about whatever societal condition they feel oppressed by. But Austen and Shakespeare allow their characters to exist in and for themselves, and the conflicts that evolve out of their interactions are maximally organic. They weave conflict out of reality, rather than depicting reality to contextualize conflict.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21554963
I should clarify, it's not that I think these are the most talented authors ever in terms of storytelling or facility of language (Joyce beats out Shakespeare in the latter, we as a civilization just haven't caught up to the Wake yet).
Rather, I think that Austen and Shakespeare are the only great authors (of those I've read) to ATTEMPT psychological objectivity. Modernist novels were all about diving INTO the subjectivity of the protagonist, ironically in a format derived from Emma. The kind of objectivity they practiced is at odds with this aim; take, for example, the scene in which Emma convinces Harriet Smith to reject Robert Martin's proposal. Much of the content of this passage consists of Emma's observations of Harriet's internal state, of a sequence of emotional and logical reactions which illustrate Harriet's internal conflict. Emma remains constant in terms of her inner journey through the sequence– the only relevant outcome of the scene is whether Harriet follows Emma's advice, or not, and to what extent Emma is culpable for the refusal. However, detail (filtered through Emma's perspective, unlike other works of Austen and Shakespeare) regarding Harriet's inner journey is lavished upon the reader, and a clear arc which bears a causal relation to Emma's, but does not CONTEXTUALIZE Emma's, is illustrated. Rather than the thematic content being gathered into a single point around the protagonist, it remains diffuse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21554970
Ulysses is the culmination of the "novel as exploration of subjective experience". That's why work since then like Gravity's Rainbow, Blood Meridian, and Infinite Jest are so disappointing, and just feel like "Ulysses but x", popified updates that don't innovate formally. Everything in Joyce is so filtered through the protagonist that events themselves are bent into allegorical significance, which has a necessarily detrimental effect on the objectivity of characterization. Not that his work would be better served by the latter, that wasn't his point.

posts.name: OP
posts.com:
>>21554963
I think that Shakespeare adopted this style mostly out of pragmatism (which is more evidence of his rusticity) and in part because literary subjectivity hadn't been refined (by Emma and Faust) yet.
Conflicts in his work arise in the intransigence of conflicting motives, and these motives exist as objects that don't necessarily hang upon the central conflict. Mercutio curses both houses of Montague and Capulet because of "who he is"; he is not reacting to Romeo's inner conflict, condemning or approving Romeo's decisions, but is instead reacting to Romeo's actions, which (from Mercutio's point of view, ignorant of Romeo and Juliet's entanglement) are that of a blood enemy of the Capulets.
In thematic terms, his death speech is a non-sequitur; Romeo has ALREADY made the resolution which would dissolve the conflict between the two families, whether in death or in marriage. Mercutio's condemnation of the houses serves to illustrate Mercutio's convictions and journey, NOT the central conflict of the play. This violates the storytelling economy which dominates subjectivity oriented literature.
Similarly, Austen's Mr Knightly comes to his resolution regarding his feelings for Emma not as a result of Emma's internal changes, but coincidentally alongside them, due to the material shifts of circumstance the events of the novel engineered between them. He realizes that he has always loved Emma, not that Emma has grown to be worthy of his love.

posts.name: OP
posts.com:
>>21555604
>reduced to think pieces
Yeah, I'd say that's accurate. Certain genres of literature are aimed at provoking a change in society, rather than introspection in individual readers. It's not a terrible thing, A Farewell to Arms and The Great Gatsby do this in part. But characters become cyphers for social classes when this is the priority. Their behavior is generally dramatized and they subject themselves to a lower degree of scrutiny than a real person would.
>how can you tell when a conflict is coming from an organic reality
I look for characters' actions being motivated by their own flawed understanding of events rather than by an accurate assessment of the protagonists views or actions. Misunderstandings are a key part of Shakespeare and Austen, and I think that's both a generic convention and a product of the realism of their characters.
I also look for characters undergoing arcs which are independent from the protagonists, not in timing or in circumstance, but in the connection between the smaller arc and the larger one being tenuous enough that the smaller doesn't seem to be designed to reflect on the larger one.
Frank Churchill and Jane Fairfax's story, for instance, is essential to Emma's own growth in terms of cause and effect, but is constructed out of thematic material that don't bear a very direct relation to that growth. They're essentially the protagonists of a separate, much more melodramatic story, one which the audience is told of in its entirety but not shown. It reminds me of the Shakespearean side characters who tell basically their whole ethos in the course of delivering a comedy scene. The commonality is that their psychological existence serves plot, moreso than theme. Because they think a certain way, they do certain things, and it's their actions rather than their thoughts which weigh on the central conflict.
